abstract.p: The backface cavity sealing flow in deeply scalloped radial turbines is numerically investigated in this article. Both the time-averaged and unsteady results are shown, and three cavity sealing geometry models are analyzed. It is found that the the sealing flow strengthens the backface casing scraping flow in the lower radial region of backface clearance, cools the root of the blade backface and prevents hot gas ingestion. With the same disk radius ratio, the model with a radial clearance shows a better performance on cooling and sealing effectiveness than that with an axial clearance. The model with a radial clearance and a larger disk radius ratio has a higher isentropic efficiency. However, the axial thrust increases drastically and the cooling effectiveness is very low. Furthermore, the sealing effectiveness for the model decreases sharply because of the larger circumferential pressure difference near the disk rim and the higher rotational Reynolds number. In transient state, the amplitude of pressure and temperature increases significantly near the disk rim. And an unsteady flow pattern with high pressure and ingestion zones rotating at twice the rotational speed in the counter rotating direction, is found on the disk backface surface.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In modern microturbines, sufficient sealing flow is channeled from the compressor to the turbine backface cavity to prevent hot gas ingestion and maintain acceptable disk temperature. The sealing flow is then injected into the mainstream which results in a reduced efficiency. In order to minimize the efficiency penalty while ensuring the durability of turbines, it is desirable to design a backface cavity and sealing geometry to control the amount of the sealing flow.

Deeply scalloped radial turbine rotors ‘scallop’ their disk to reduce weight and centrifugal stress (Figure 1), and are widely used in modern microturbines. However, the thermal stress is very high in the integral cast disk of deeply scalloped radial turbines. Failure to use backface cavity sealing flow seriously limits the radial turbine life and it has been overlooked in several early engines,1 an example was the disk backface crack found in a small engine2 due to the hot gas ingestion. Figure 1.
Deeply scalloped radial turbine rotors: (a) RD = 0.64; and (b) RD = 0.8.

The disk pumping effect and the periodic vane or blade pressure field (steady and unsteady) are the two major mechanisms in the hot gas ingestion process.3 Early work concentrated on the disk pumping effect for simple disk geometry without blade and external flows. It was found that radial clearance seal required smaller amount of sealing flow than the axial clearance seal,4 and the minimum sealing flow rate necessary to prevent ingress (Cw,min) was found to be related to the normalized sealing clearance (Gc) and rotational Reynolds number (Reθ) by the equation Cw,min = 0.61GcReθ.5 More recently, the disk pumping effect was referred to as rotationally induced (RI) ingress by Owen.6

In comparison with the rotationally induced ingress, the circumferential pressure asymmetry due to the periodic vanes or blades are generally thought to be the primary cause of hot gas ingestion, and that was referred to as externally induced (EI) ingress.7 An early study conducted by Campbell8 indicated that the presence of a circumferentially asymmetric external flow tended to increase ingestion. And this was confirmed by the experimental studies in Kobayashi et al.,9 Phadke and Owen,10,11 and Chew et al.12 Unsteady effects play an important role in the hot gas ingestion process. Bohn et al.13 measured the pressure distribution and sealing effectiveness in a turbine stage and an ingestion zone with half rotor speed was numerically predicted. Roy et al.14 presented the time-averaged and unsteady pressure distributions on the outer shroud and stator disk surfaces in a turbine stage. The unsteady analysis indicated that along with the high amplitude at the blade passing frequency, a low amplitude frequency was also found in the rim seal region. And this unsteady feature was also reported by Cao et al.15 and Hills et al.16 conducted a numerical study on hot gas ingestion using four computational fluid dynamics (CFD) models. It was found that the steady simulation cannot capture the ingestion, whereas the unsteady results showed a good agreement with the pressure and sealing effectiveness measurement data. Recently, Bunker et al.17 and Laskowski et al.18 conducted a combined experimental and numerical study on hot gas ingestion in a cascade rig. Favorable agreement was shown between the time-averaged simulation results and the experimental data.

The impact of the sealing flow on the turbine efficiency is also considerable. Denton19 indicated that the swirl velocity difference between the sealing flow and the mainstream was the major source of entropy generation. Mclean et al.20 investigated the influence of the sealing flow in an axial turbine. It was indicated that even a small amount of sealing flow could have significant effects on the distribution of aerodynamic parameters at the outlet. In radial turbines, the efficiency penalty due to the sealing flow was also considerable as indicated by Hiett et al.21 and Rogo.22

All the work mentioned above focused on the cavity sealing flow in axial turbines. However, there is little literature concerning the backface cavity sealing flow in deeply scalloped radial turbines. Sun et al.23 studied the flow structure in the backface cavity of a centrifugal compressor. The pressure and velocity fields in the cavity were shown and the influence of the cavity flow on the efficiency and axial thrust was also discussed. He et al.24,25 investigated the backface clearance flow in a deeply scalloped radial turbine. However, the backface cavity flow was not studied in the literature. The backface cavity was included in the conjugate heat transfer investigation conducted by Heuer et al.,26 Verstraete et al.27 and Bohn et al.,28 whereas the behavior of the cavity sealing flow was not further discussed. Investigation on backface cavity sealing flow could provide a good reference for choosing proper scallop (disk) radius and sealing geometry, which could significantly influence both the efficiency and durability of deeply scalloped radial turbines.

This article presents a numerical study of backface cavity sealing flow in deeply scalloped radial turbines for three sealing geometries. Both the time-averaged and unsteady results are shown and the influence of the sealing flow on the backface clearance flow, isentropic efficiency, axial thrust, cooling and sealing effectiveness is discussed. And an optimal sealing geometry is recommended at last.

sec.title: Numerical method
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the 3D image of the deeply scalloped radial turbine rotors investigated in this article. The turbine was originally designed with 23 stator vanes and 13 rotor blades. However, in order to perform unsteady calculation, the stator is re-designed with 26 vanes and the profile of the vanes is modified to maintain the same aerodynamic performance. The computational domain consists of 2 stator vanes and 1 rotor blade with backface cavity, the pitch ratio of the stator and rotor domains is 1:1. Figure 2 presents the meridional view of the deeply scalloped radial turbine and the backface cavity. Three different sealing geometries are considered. Seal 1 and seal 2 are sealing geometries with radial and axial clearance respectively, and their disk radius ratio is 0.64 (RD = 0.64). Seal 3 is a radial clearance geometry model with a bigger disk radius ratio (RD = 0.8). The sealing clearance ratio (Gc) for the three sealing geometries is 0.01. The sealing flow enters the cavity at the lower radial position and then flows outwards. After cooling the disk backface, the sealing flow is injected into the mainstream at the disk rim. Figure 2.
Meridional view of the deeply scalloped radial turbine and the backface cavity for the three sealing geometries: (a) seal 1 (radial clearance, RD = 0.64); (b) seal 2 (axial clearance, RD = 0.64); and (c) seal 3 (radial clearance, RD = 0.8).

A simple cavity model is used in this article for CFD verification. The cavity is comprised of a shrouded stator and a rotating disk. The sealing flow is injected into the cavity through the center hole of the stator and finally ejected into the atmosphere. The detailed geometry information of the cavity model can be seen in Phadke and Owen.4

Structured meshes are generated using ANSYS ICEM for both calculations. The average Y+ is about 1 for both meshes. The total mesh number is about 2.8 million (stator ∼0.9 million and rotor ∼ 1.9 million) for the radial turbine and 0.3 million for the simple cavity model. Figure 3 shows the meshes of the radial turbine with backface cavity and the simple cavity model. The coarse meshes are presented for better visualization. Figure 3.
Meshes of the radial turbine and the simple cavity: (a) radial turbine with backface cavity; and (b) simple cavity model.

The calculations are performed using ANSYS CFX, and the solutions are obtained by solving Navier–Stokes equations. At the stator inlet, total pressure (375.6 kPa) and total temperature (1150 K) are specified along with a radial flow angle (0°) and a medium turbulent intensity (5%). At the backface cavity inlet, total temperature (575 K) and mass flow are specified. At the rotor outlet, average static pressure (96 kPa) is specified. The rotational periodic boundary condition is imposed on the periodic boundaries. And the non-slip and adiabatic conditions are applied on the blades and walls. The low Reynolds number SST k–ω turbulence model, which gives highly accurate prediction of the flow separation, is used during the simulation. A steady result is obtained before the unsteady calculation and the result is used as the initial value for the transient simulation. For the unsteady calculation, a sliding interface is presented between stator and rotor domains. And 30 time steps are specified for one blade passing period, each time step is 3.4188 × 10−6 s. The unsteady simulation proceeds for 900 time steps (30 blade passing periods) to obtain the final solution.

For the simple cavity model, a 2° sector domain is simulated. Total temperature (288 K) and mass flow are specified at the cavity inlet. An opening condition (101.3 kPa, 288 K) is imposed on the outer surface of the atmosphere region (Figure 3(b)).

sec.title: CFD Verification
sec.p:
The pressure and velocity fields were measured in a simple cavity model4 and it is used for CFD verification. The static pressure taps were fitted on the stator disk to obtain the radial variation of pressure. Figure 4(a) and (b) shows the comparisons of pressure distribution on the stator disk for different Cw and Reθ. One can see that the calculated pressure distribution agrees reasonably well with the experimental data. The velocity probe was inserted into the cavity to measure the axial variation of tangential velocity. Figure 4(c) presents the comparison of tangential velocity at normalized radius of 0.81 (R = 0.81) in the cavity for different Cw. The calculated velocity distribution is generally in good agreement with the experimental data, although the predicted velocity is slightly lower than the measured data for Cw = 1490. The flow structure visualization in the cavity was achieved by injecting smoke into the sealing flow, and using a laser to provide slit illumination. Based on the measurement results, Phadke and Owen4 provided a schematic view of the flow structure. Figure 4(d) shows the comparison of flow structure in the cavity. Two vortexes were found in the experiment and they are well captured by the CFD simulation. Figure 4.
Comparisons of the CFD result and the experimental data4: (a) pressure distribution on the stator disk (Cw = 1490); (b) pressure distribution on the stator disk (Cw = 2950); (c) tangential velocity in the cavity (R = 0.81); and (d) flow structure in the cavity.
CFD: computational fluid dynamics.

From the above comparisons, one can see that the calculated results agree well with the experimental data and CFX successfully simulates the pressure and velocity fields in the cavity. Another CFD verification, which focused on the flow field in a deeply scalloped radial turbine, can be seen in our previous work.25 These two verification studies could provide a good indication for the present investigation on the combined system of radial turbine and backface cavity.

sec.title: Influence of the backface cavity sealing flow on the backface clearance flow
sec.p: In the previous investigation on the backface clearance flow,25 the sealing flow is ignored. However, the interface between the backface cavity and the blade passage is located at the lower radial position of the backface clearance (Figure 2). The sealing flow interacts with the backface clearance flow in this region and that will be discussed in this section.

Figure 5(a) shows the flow structure of the backface cavity sealing flow in the radial turbine. The sealing flow is injected into the cavity at the lower radial position, swirled by the rotation of the disk in the backface cavity, and then mixed into the mainstream. After impinging on the root corner of the blade suction surface, the sealing flow is divided into two branches. The suction side branch of the sealing flow (FS) stays close to the suction surface due to the circumferential pressure gradient, and moves towards the blade tip under the influence of the centrifugal force. The pressure side branch of the sealing flow (FP) flows through the backface clearance in the lower radial region and migrates to the suction surface of the next blade. These two branches of sealing flows finally merge together at the rotor outlet. Figure 5.
Influence of the backface cavity sealing flow on the backface clearance flow: (a) flow structure of the sealing flow (seal 1, MR = 1%); (b) time-averaged net mass flow in the backface clearance for different MR (seal 1); (c) time-averaged limiting streamlines on the blade backface surface for different MR (seal 1); and (d) interaction of the sealing flow and the backface clearance flows.

There are two flows in the backface clearance as indicated in He et al.25 They are backface clearance leakage flow and the backface casing scraping flow (caused by the backface casing relative motion). Figure 5(b) presents the time-averaged net mass flow in the backface clearance for different mass flow ratios (MR). The net mass flow is defined as the leakage mass flow minus the scraping mass flow. The positive net mass flow means the leakage flow is dominant in the backface clearance and vice versa. In comparison with the non-sealing flow condition (MR = 0), the net mass flow decreases more rapidly in the lower radial region with the injection of the sealing flow, which means the intensity of the scraping flow increases. However, in the upper radial region, the net mass flow does not change much.

The time-averaged limiting streamlines on the blade backface for different MR can be seen in Figure 5(c). There is a reattachment zone in the upper radial region caused by the separation of the leakage flow and a recirculation zone in the lower radial region due to the weakened leakage flow and the dominant scraping flow.25 With the injection of the sealing flow, the recirculation zone, in which the intensities of the leakage and the scraping flows are nearly the same, moves towards the upper radial position because of the strengthened scraping flow, whereas the reattachment zone remains unchanged. It can be concluded that the pressure side branch of the sealing flow (FP) strengthens the intensity of the scraping flow in the lower radial region. However, in the upper radial region, the flow structure in the backface clearance, including the relative intensity of the leakage and the scraping flows and the reattachment zone, remains the same. This can be illustrated more clearly in Figure 5(d), where the interaction of the backface clearance flows and the backface cavity sealing flow is shown schematically. The major flow structure of the backface clearance flow in He et al.25 is unchanged.

sec.title: Influence of the backface cavity sealing flow on the efficiency and axial thrust
sec.p:
The influence of the mass flow ratio on the turbine isentropic efficiency (ηis, see Notation for definition) and axial thrust is shown in Figure 6 based on the steady results. Overall, the isentropic efficiency decreases by 0.4% with increasing the sealing flow rate by 1% (Figure 6(a)). Seal 1 and seal 2 have a similar efficiency distribution, but seal 3 has a higher efficiency than seals 1 and 2 with the same sealing flow rate. This is due to the smoother hub profile (Figure 2) and smaller backface clearance loss.29 However, the axial thrust for seal 3 is much higher than those for seals 1 and 2 (Figure 6(b)). This is because, with a higher disk radius, the area of the disk backface is larger for seal 3. In addition, the interface between the backface cavity and the blade passage is much closer to the blade inlet, and the pressure in the backface cavity increases significantly. These result in a higher axial thrust (FA = pressure × area) for seal 3. The higher axial thrust is undesirable for the durability of turbine bearings. Figure 6.
Influence of MR on the isentropic efficiency and axial thrust: (a) isentropic efficiency; and (b) axial thrust.

sec.title: Influence of the backface cavity sealing flow on the cooling effectiveness
sec.p: The root of the blade backface is one of the life limiting regions of radial turbine rotors because of the high centrifugal stress.30 Unfortunately, this region is subjected to relatively high heat transfer coefficient due to the impingement of the strong backface casing scraping flow.25 The backface cavity sealing flow can cool this region and the thermal load can be reduced as shown in Figure 5(a) and (d). The cooling effectiveness of the sealing flow will be discussed as follows.

The time-averaged cooling effectiveness (ηc, see Notation for definition) for different seals (MR = 1%) is presented in Figure 7. Overall, seal 3 has the lowest cooling effectiveness because of the large angle between the injection direction of the sealing flow and the hub profile (Figure 2(c)). The cooling effectiveness for seal 1 is higher than that for seal 2 on the hub surface (Figure 7(b)), especially in the lower axial distance (Z) region. However, on the suction surface, the cooling effectiveness for seal 1 is relatively low (Figure 7(c)). This is because the radial injection of the sealing flow in seal 2 (axial clearance) can cool the suction surface more effectively. However, in this case, the hub surface is hard to be cooled. Figure 7.
Influence of the sealing flow (MR = 1%) on the cooling effectiveness (ηc): (a) contours of time-averaged cooling effectiveness for different seals; (b) distributions of the averaged cooling effectiveness along axial distance (hub surface); and (c) distributions of the averaged cooling effectiveness along axial distance (suction surface).

sec.title: Influence of the backface cavity sealing flow on the hot gas ingestion feature
sec.p: In axial turbines, the sealing flow is injected into the mainstream prior to the rotor blades. The asymmetric pressure field just aft of the stator vanes is thought to be the major cause of hot gas ingestion. For deeply scalloped radial turbines, the injection position of the sealing flow is located in the blade passage (Figure 2), where the asymmetric pressure variation caused by the stator wakes is relatively small. However, in the blade passage, there is a circumferential pressure gradient due to the blade loading. The hot gas ingestion feature of the backface cavity sealing flow in deeply scalloped radial turbines will be analyzed as follows.

The time-averaged pressure distribution on the backface casing (Figure 2) surface is shown in Figure 8(a) and (b). For seal 1, there is an obviously asymmetric pressure variation in the upper radial region (R = 1.3, R = 1.5). However, near the disk rim (R = 1), the amplitude of the circumferential pressure difference becomes much lower. This is because, in the inlet section of deeply scalloped radial turbines, the circumferential pressure gradient is mainly determined by the Coriolis force25 as shown in equation (1). This circumferential pressure gradient is responsible for the blade loading and the asymmetric pressure variation in the upper radial region. However, around the region of disk rim (R = 1), the flow direction is forced to change from radial to axial (Figure 2(a)). The radial velocity decreases rapidly and so do the Coriolis force and the circumferential pressure gradient. This is favorable for the sealing of hot gas. However, for seal 3, the hub profile is smoother and the decrement of radial velocity near the disk rim is relatively low (Figure 2(c)). Therefore, the pressure difference at the lower radial location (R = 1) is much higher than that for seal 1. On the other hand, for seal 3, the disk radius is higher and so does the intensity of the rotationally induced ingress (higher rotational Reynolds number). These two factors are unfavorable for the sealing of hot gas. (1)1ρr∂P∂θ=-2Wrω Figure 8.
Influence of the sealing flow on the sealing effectiveness (ηs): (a) time-averaged pressure distribution on the backface casing surface (seal 1, MR = 1%); (b) time-averaged pressure distribution on the backface casing surface (seal 3, MR = 1%); (c) contours of the time-averaged sealing effectiveness in the cavities for different seals; and (d) time-averaged sealing effectiveness distribution on the disk backface surfaces for different seals.

Figure 8(c) and (d) presents the time-averaged sealing effectiveness (ηs, see Notation for definition) distribution in the cavities and on the disk backface (Figure 2) surfaces respectively. As mentioned above, with a larger circumferential pressure difference and disk radius, the sealing effectiveness for seal 3 is much lower than those for seals 1 and 2. Even with a larger sealing flow rate (MR = 2%), the sealing effectiveness on the disk backface surface for seal 3 is still lower than that for seal 1 with a lower sealing flow rate (MR = 1%). In addition, the efficiency penalty for seal 3 is also greater in this case (Figure 6(a), MR = 2%). Although seal 1 and seal 2 have a similar sealing performance in the lower radial region of the cavity, the sealing effectiveness for seal 2 decreases rapidly in the region of R > 0.9. The sealing effectiveness reduction for seal 1 is relatively small due to the benefit of the axial buffer section (Figure 8(c)) near the disk rim, and the sealing effectiveness is larger than 0.9 in the whole cavity.

Table 1 summarizes the overall performance of the three seals (MR = 1%), and seal 1 is used as the standard value (std) for comparison. The cooling and sealing effectiveness (ηc and ηs) are the average value around the disk rim region (Z < 0.1 for ηc and R > 0.9 for ηs). In general, seal 3 has the lowest cooling and sealing effectiveness. Although the isentropic efficiency for seal 3 is relatively high, more sealing flow is needed to prevent ingestion (MR > 2%) and the efficiency penalty will be larger. On the other hand, seal 1 (radial clearance sealing geometry) shows a better performance on cooling and sealing effectiveness than seal 2 (axial clearance sealing geometry). Although seal 1 and seal 2 have a similar sealing performance in the lower radial region of the cavity, the sealing effectiveness near the disk rim region for seal 2 is much lower than that for seal 1. Therefore, seal 1, with the radial clearance sealing geometry and lower disk rim radius, is the best among the three geometries and is recommended for the deeply scalloped radial turbine. Table 1.

sec.title: Unsteady feature of the backface cavity sealing flow in the backface cavity
sec.p: The unsteady flow in the mainstream of radial turbines has been investigated by many researchers.31–34 However, the unsteady effect in the backface cavity of deeply scalloped radial turbines is not yet clear. The hot gas ingestion feature in transient state will be discussed in this section.

Figure 9(a) and (b) presents the unsteady pressure and temperature at the monitor points (Figure 2(a)) on the disk backface (R < 1) and blade backface (R > 1) surfaces for seal 1. A regular periodic distribution of pressure and temperature is found at the upper radial location (R = 1.5). However, at the lower radial locations, due to the interaction of the backface sealing flow and the mainstream, the pressure and temperature variations are much more irregular. Figure 9(c) and (d) presents the results in frequency space by performing a fast Fourier transform analysis (FFT) of the transient pressure and temperature at the monitor points. There is a main frequency (f/frot) of 26 for all the radial locations (R). The high amplitude of pressure fluctuation is due to the influence of the stator passing wakes on the blade and disk backface surfaces (f/frot = zstator = 26). In the blade passage, the intensity of the stator wakes is reduced along the streamwise direction, so the amplitude of pressure fluctuation decreases against the radial direction in the upper radial region (Figure 9(c)). However, near the disk rim (R = 1), the amplitude increases drastically. The corresponding temperature fluctuation is also considerable (Figure 9(d)), which will lead to the unsteady hot gas ingestion. Besides the main frequency, a lower frequency of 6.5 (f/frot = 0.25zstator = 6.5) is also found near the disk rim. And this second amplitude, lower frequency unsteady pattern was also observed in axial turbine cavities.14,15 Figure 9.
Unsteady pressure and temperature at the monitor points on the disk backface (R < 1) and blade backface (R > 1) surfaces for seal 1: (a) transient pressure; (b) transient temperature; (c) FFT analysis of the transient pressure; and (d) FFT analysis of the transient temperature.
FFT: fast Fourier transform.

Figure 10(a) and (b) presents the transient contour of pressure and sealing effectiveness on the disk backface surface for seal 1. As shown in Figure 9(c), the amplitude of the unsteady pressure is relatively high at the location of R = 1, and a high pressure zone is found near the disk rim in transient state (Figure 10(a)). The high pressure drives the hot gas to ingress into the cavity, and the sealing effectiveness is relatively low in this region (ingestion zone in Figure 10(b)). This high pressure-high ingestion flow pattern was also found in axial turbines.13 In the transient state of t = 0, the ingestion zone is located near the suction side of the blade (Figure 10(b)). With the blade rotating, the ingestion zone moves on the disk backface in the counter-rotating direction. Finally, in the transient state of t = 0.5Tblade (half blade passing period), the ingestion zone migrates to the suction side of the next blade, which means the ingestion zone moves at twice the rotational speed in the counter-rotating direction on the disk backface surface. Figure 10.
Unsteady contour of pressure and sealing effectiveness on the disk backface surface for seal 1: (a) pressure; and (b) sealing effectiveness.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
This article investigates the backface cavity sealing flow in deeply scalloped radial turbines for three sealing geometries, and the following conclusions can be drawn.
In comparison with the no backface cavity sealing flow case, the sealing flow strengthens the scraping flow in the lower radial region of backface clearance, whereas the major flow structure, including the separation, reattachment and recirculation of the backface clearance flow, remains the same.
The sealing geometry with a radial clearance and a larger disk radius ratio (seal 3) has a higher isentropic efficiency than the other two seals due to the smoother hub profile and less backface clearance loss. However, with the larger disk radius ratio, the axial thrust for seal 3 is greater because of the larger disk backface area and the higher pressure in the backface cavity.
With a smaller angle between the injection direction of the sealing flow and the hub profile, the sealing geometry with a radial clearance and a smaller disk radius ratio (seal 1) has the highest cooling effectiveness which could reduce the thermal load at the root of the blade backface effectively.
With the same disk radius ratio, the sealing geometry with a radial clearance (seal 1) shows a better performance on sealing effectiveness than that with an axial clearance (seal 2). On the other hand, with a larger disk radius, the sealing effectiveness for seal 3 decreases drastically because of the greater circumferential pressure difference near the disk rim and the higher rotational Reynolds number.
In transient state, there is a sharp increment of pressure and temperature amplitudes near the disk rim and the unsteadily induced ingestion is considerable. An unsteady flow pattern with high pressure and ingestion zones rotating at twice the rotational speed in the counter rotating direction, is found on the disk backface surface.
